20110117222045.000|20110117222047.000|TR0|LISA SYLVESTER, CNN CORRESPONDENT:  Hi

20110117222922.000|20110117222924.000|TR0|CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): More tear gas

20110117222926.000|20110117222929.000|TR0|are marching on headquarters of the ruling 
20110117222929.000|20110117222931.000|TR0|party.  Street protests brought down

20110117222933.000|20110117222935.000|TR0|but many Tunisians insist that was the

20110117223015.000|20110117223018.000|TR0|LANGUAGE) free.
20110117223018.000|20110117223020.000|TR0|
20110117223020.000|20110117223022.000|TR0|WEDEMAN:  Many Tunisians credit the army 
20110117223022.000|20110117223024.000|TR0|with dealing the final blow to the old 
20110117223024.000|20110117223026.000|TR0|regime by standing down the day before Ben 
20110117223026.000|20110117223029.000|TR0|Ali fled.  In the Tunis working class 
20110117223029.000|20110117223031.000|TR0|district, a Sudaman (ph), small but vocal 
20110117223031.000|20110117223033.000|TR0|group joins in the call for a clean slate. 
20110117223033.000|20110117223035.000|TR0| It was here that the first anti-regime 
20110117223035.000|20110117223038.000|TR0|protest in the capital broke out, and now, 
20110117223038.000|20110117223040.000|TR0|they want power.
20110117223040.000|20110117223042.000|TR0|
20110117223042.000|20110117223044.000|TR0|We want a government that represents us, 
20110117223044.000|20110117223047.000|TR0|says Ali, a government employee.  We made 
20110117223047.000|20110117223049.000|TR0|this revolution.  We shed our blood for 
20110117223049.000|20110117223051.000|TR0|the revolution.
20110117223051.000|20110117223053.000|TR0|
20110117223053.000|20110117223055.000|TR0|Unemployed worker, Riyad (ph), says we 
20110117223055.000|20110117223058.000|TR0|demand the withdrawal from the government 
20110117223058.000|20110117223100.000|TR0|of every minister, every official from the 
20110117223100.000|20110117223102.000|TR0|previous government. By late afternoon, 
20110117223102.000|20110117223104.000|TR0|the capital was quiet again.  Residents 
20110117223104.000|20110117223107.000|TR0|making their way home before the start of 
20110117223107.000|20110117223109.000|TR0|the nightly curfew, but the revolution 
20110117223109.000|20110117223111.000|TR0|that is sweeping this once sleepy country 
20110117223111.000|20110117223113.000|TR0|seems to be on everyone's mind.  Tariq, an 
20110117223113.000|20110117223115.000|TR0|engineering student, can now utter a 
20110117223115.000|20110117223118.000|TR0|simple word of profound significance.

20110117223122.000|20110117223124.000|TR0|changed?  Yesterday, we can't say no.  
20110117223124.000|20110117223127.000|TR0|Today, I came to say no for anyone.

20110117223149.000|20110117223151.000|TR0|BLITZER:  The tensions between North Korea

20110117223153.000|20110117223156.000|TR0|American military families in a very, very

20110117223158.000|20110117223200.000|TR0|answers about loved ones who served in the 
20110117223200.000|20110117223202.000|TR0|Korean wars some 60 years ago.  Our

20110117223300.000|20110117223302.000|TR0|War.

20110117224010.000|20110117224012.000|TR0|sort of gets away from that for an 
20110117224012.000|20110117224015.000|TR0|extended period of time is probably not 
20110117224015.000|20110117224017.000|TR0|that helpful.  I mean, certainly there's 
20110117224017.000|20110117224019.000|TR0|some political benefit in bringing this 
20110117224019.000|20110117224021.000|TR0|up, but there's about less than zero 
20110117224021.000|20110117224023.000|TR0|chance that the House of Representatives 
20110117224023.000|20110117224026.000|TR0|would do anything to -- that would upset 
20110117224026.000|20110117224028.000|TR0|the NRA, and that's just a fact of 
20110117224028.000|20110117224030.000|TR0|political life.

20110117224411.000|20110117224413.000|TR0|BRIAN TODD, CNN CORRESPONDENT:  Checking 
20110117224413.000|20110117224415.000|TR0|into a statute in Arizona state law, Wolf, 
20110117224415.000|20110117224417.000|TR0|and there is one that talks about a 
20110117224417.000|20110117224420.000|TR0|vacancy and what will happen if a vacancy 
20110117224420.000|20110117224422.000|TR0|is defined there.  And according to this 
20110117224422.000|20110117224424.000|TR0|Arizona state law, an office shall be 
20110117224424.000|20110117224426.000|TR0|deemed vacant -- this is one of the 
20110117224426.000|20110117224428.000|TR0|statutes -- if "The person holding the 
20110117224428.000|20110117224431.000|TR0|office ceasing to discharge the duties of 
20110117224431.000|20110117224433.000|TR0|office for the period of three consecutive 
20110117224433.000|20110117224435.000|TR0|months."
20110117224435.000|20110117224437.000|TR0|
20110117224437.000|20110117224440.000|TR0|That's when they deem the office to be 
20110117224440.000|20110117224442.000|TR0|vacant.  They could conceivably hold a 
20110117224442.000|20110117224444.000|TR0|special election if that office is deemed 
20110117224444.000|20110117224446.000|TR0|to be vacant, if Congresswoman Giffords 
20110117224446.000|20110117224449.000|TR0|cannot discharge her duties for three 
20110117224449.000|20110117224451.000|TR0|consecutive months.  But there is a lot of 
20110117224451.000|20110117224453.000|TR0|gray area here.
20110117224453.000|20110117224455.000|TR0|
20110117224455.000|20110117224457.000|TR0|What does it mean that she can't discharge 
20110117224457.000|20110117224500.000|TR0|her duties?  Could she possibly vote?  
20110117224500.000|20110117224502.000|TR0|Could she make other decisions even while 
20110117224502.000|20110117224504.000|TR0|she's recovering in the hospital?  Not 
20110117224504.000|20110117224506.000|TR0|clear at all, but it is in the statute 
20110117224506.000|20110117224509.000|TR0|that an office will be deemed vacant if 
20110117224509.000|20110117224511.000|TR0|the person fails to discharge their duties 
20110117224511.000|20110117224513.000|TR0|for three consecutive months.
20110117224513.000|20110117224515.000|TR0|
